content:
How to Check if Windows is 32‐Bits or 64‐Bits: 7 Steps 
 Home Random Browse Articles Notifications Add to This Page Add Tip Easy Ways to Help Approve Questions Review Tech Feedback Fix Spelling More Things to Try...   
 Log in / Sign up   
 Desktop Site   
 Community Tested How to Check if Windows is 32‐Bits or 64‐Bits   
 This wikiHow teaches you how to determine your Windows computer's bit count, which typically will be either 32- or 64-bit. 
 10 Second Summary Edit 
 1. Right-click the  Start  icon. 
2. Click  System . 
3. Look for  32-bit  or  64-bit  to the right of the "System type" heading. 
 Steps Edit 
 Method One of Two: Windows 10 and 8 Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-1-Version-6.jpg\/v4-459px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-1-Version-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/74\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-1-Version-6.jpg\/v4-759px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-1-Version-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344.36813186813,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.95604395604} 
 1 
 Right-click the Start icon.  It's the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen. Doing so invokes a pop-up menu.
 If you don't see this icon, instead press  ⊞  Win + X . 
 If you're using a laptop with a trackpad, tap the trackpad with two fingers instead of right-clicking. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/7f\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-2-Version-6.jpg\/v4-460px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-2-Version-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/7f\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-2-Version-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Click  System .  You should see this option near the top of the pop-up menu.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/47\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-3-Version-6.jpg\/v4-460px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-3-Version-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/47\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-3-Version-6.jpg\/v4-760px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-3-Version-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Look for the "System type" heading.  It's below the "Installed RAM" heading on this page. You'll see either "64-bit" or "32-bit" to the right of "System type"; this is your computer's bit count.
 Advertisement 
 Method Two of Two: Windows 7 Edit 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8c\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-4-Version-6.jpg\/v4-460px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-4-Version-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8c\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-4-Version-6.jpg\/v4-760px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-4-Version-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 1 
 Open Start.  Either click the Windows logo in the bottom-right corner of the screen, or press the  ⊞  Win  key.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/72\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-5-Version-6.jpg\/v4-460px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-5-Version-6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/7\/72\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-5-Version-6.jpg\/v4-760px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-5-Version-6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 2 
 Right-click  Computer .  It's on the right side of the Start window. Doing so invokes a drop-down menu.
 If the My Computer app is on your desktop, you can right-click it instead. 
 If you're using a laptop with a trackpad, tap the trackpad with two fingers instead of right-clicking. 
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b7\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-6-Version-5.jpg\/v4-460px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-6-Version-5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b7\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-6-Version-5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 3 
 Click  Properties .  This option is near the bottom of the drop-down menu.
 {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/39\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-7-Version-5.jpg\/v4-460px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-7-Version-5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/39\/Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-7-Version-5.jpg\/v4-760px-Check-if-Windows-Is-32-Bits-or-64-Bits-Step-7-Version-5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570} 
 4 
 Look for the "System type" heading.  It's below the "Installed RAM" heading on this page. You'll see either "64-bit" or "32-bit" to the right of "System type"; this is your computer's bit count.
 Advertisement 
 Community Q&A 
 Search 
 Add New Question 
 I'm building a new computer and have selected the AMD Athlon 760k Richland 3.8GHz. Is this a 64-bit processor? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 This is, in fact, a 64-bit processor.  
 Thanks! 
 3 
 1 
 Is there an easy way to install a 64-bit processor? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 Yes, open up the PC. Look for a big fan. Unscrew the fan. Underneath the fan is a processor. Take out the processor. Put in a 64 bit processor (must purchase separately). Apply thermal paste. Put the fan back on. Close the computer. 
 Thanks! 
 0 
 0 
 I have a 32-bit processor, how can I get a 64-bit processor? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 You buy one by going on Amazon and finding a chip that is compatible with your motherboard. Or delete Windows 32 by going into the Windows file on My PC and delete it. 
 Thanks! 
 0 
 1 
 What is a 64 bit PC? 
								Answered by  
								wikiHow Contributor							 
 The terms 32-bit and 64-bit refer to the way a computer's processor (also called a CPU), handles information. The 64-bit version of Windows handles large amounts of random access memory (RAM) more effectively than a 32-bit system. 
 Thanks! 
 0 
 2 
 So can you still play the game if you have Windows XP or not? I can't afford to get another op system?

 Tips Edit 
 You can typically determine a Windows computer's bit count by looking at its system specifications in a store or online.

 Warnings Edit 
 Attempting to run a 64-bit program on a 32-bit system will generally result in problems.
